Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Gerald B. Hammond of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Louisville will investigate fluorine-gold activation processes that can mediate tandem sequences leading to novel metal-mediated nucleophilic addition/coupling/fluorination reactions, which, in turn, should lead to efficient synthesis of organofluoro compounds. Even though fluorine has a unique ability to modify the physico-chemical properties of a compound, its introduction on small molecules is usually cumbersome. Indeed, the syntheses of fluorinated aliphatic and cyclic systems require tedious reagents or synthetic procedures that rely on a small pool of commercial fluorine-containing building blocks. The mechanism-based approach of this research will enable the synthesis of aliphatic organofluoro compounds, such as fluoroketones and fluoroheterocycles in a medicinal chemistry-friendly manner, utilizing cationic metal species capable of metal-mediated fluorinations, oxidations or couplings, and readily available alkynes or alkenes as starting materials. Ultimately, the work proposed on fluorine-engendered cationic species will yield substantial insights on the interaction of fluorine and transition metals.

The broader impact of this project is that its well-defined modules are suitable for training a younger generation of students and postdoctoral fellows in organofluorine chemistry, a research area that is performed by a handful of scientists in the U.S., compared to other industrialized nations, despite the ever-increasing importance of fluorine in the medicinal or agrochemical fields. This project will impact the manufacturing field broadly defined because it will give ready access to fluorinated compounds in a diversified manner and with fewer synthetic steps.

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original goals of the project were i) to investigate reaction pathways conducive to the gold-catalyzed synthesis of fluorinated or non-fluorinated products, and ii) to develop an efficient and medicinal chemistry-friendly synthesis of fluorinated compounds. During this four-year project, which included a no-cost one year extension, we spent much effort in understanding the basic mechanism of gold-catalyzed reactions for which we carried in depth physical organic chemistry studies. As a result we devised a set of rules to rationally design phosphine ligands for gold catalyzed reactions. We also uncovered structural features in phosphine ligands that enhanced the efficiency of gold-catalyzed reactions through decay slowdown and increased turnover number (TON). In addition, we began to understand the role of additives in ionic reactions and we expanded the range of transition-metal mediated fluorinations. Our most recent results showed that some organic salts with a large counterion, when used as additives, could boost significantly a variety of ionic reactions. We also found that additives with strong hydrogen bonding activities (pKBHX) could expand the usefulness of fluorinations.

 

What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project?

Our new findings on ligands and additives have provided tools that may be enhance the rate and yield of other chemical reactions, including basic fluorine substitutions. Our research has led us into a serious introspection of the role of counterions and hydrogen bonding in ionic reactions. We are currently formulating new rules for enhancing the usefulness of counterion size and high hydrogen bonding basicity (pKBHX)--a relatively new concept--in a wide array of ionic reactions.

 

What is the impact on other disciplines?

We have found a new ligand for gold catalysts and a new additive, both of which are highly efficient and broadly applicable, and are now commercialized worldwide through the Sigma-Aldrich Company. Enhancing the rate and efficiency of chemical reactions may also lead to environmental friendlier procedures and productivity gains in the manufacturing industry.

 

What are the broader impacts of this project?

In terms of development of human resources, this project has contributed to the training of 11 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students, and 1 research assistant professor. Five of the graduate students involved in this four-year project obtained their doctorate, three found employment elsewhere as postdoctoral fellows, one is an assistant professor in an Indian university and one is employed in industry in Florida. The remaining graduate students are continuing with their doctoral research in my lab. I started international collaborations with professors from universities from Germany (Heidelberg University), Japan (Gunma University) and Brazil (University of Santa Maria). These collaborations led to the arrival of three graduate students from those countries that spent two to four-month long research internships in my lab. One of them has already coauthored a publication with members of my group.

In terms of dissemination of results, our group published 25 papers in high impact, peer-reviewed journals, and one book chapter; we were also granted an international (PCT) patent on a potential anticancer drug. My students and I presented our results in 8 international, national and regional scientific meetings, and I gave seminars in 22 universities across the U.S., England, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Japan, and Peru.

In 2014, I initiated a ‘Targeting Excellence: Hispanic Latino Student Initiative’ at the University of Louisville. This annual research symposium, held during Hispanic Heritage month, features high-profile Hispanic-American serving as role mode...

During this four-year project, which included a no-cost one year extension, we spent much effort in understanding the basic mechanism of gold-catalyzed reactions for which we carried in depth physical organic chemistry studies. As a result we devised a set of rules to rationally design phosphine ligands for gold catalyzed reactions. We also uncovered structural features in phosphine ligands that enhanced the efficiency of gold-catalyzed reactions through decay slowdown and increased turnover number (TON). In addition, we began to understand the role of additives in ionic reactions and we expanded the range of transition-metal mediated fluorinations. Our most recent results showed that some organic salts with a large counterion, when used as additives, could boost significantly a variety of ionic reactions. We also found that additives with strong hydrogen bonding activities (pKBHX) could expand the usefulness of fluorinations. What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project? Our new findings on ligands and additives have provided tools that may be enhance the rate and yield of other chemical reactions, including basic fluorine substitutions. Our research has led us into a serious introspection of the role of counterions and hydrogen bonding in ionic reactions. We are currently formulating new rules for enhancing the usefulness of counterion size and high hydrogen bonding basicity (pKBHX)--a relatively new concept--in a wide array of ionic reactions. What is the impact on other disciplines? We have found a new ligand for gold catalysts and a new additive, both of which are highly efficient and broadly applicable, and are now commercialized worldwide through the Sigma-Aldrich Company. Enhancing the rate and efficiency of chemical reactions may also lead to environmental friendlier procedures and productivity gains in the manufacturing industry. What are the broader impacts of this project? In terms of development of human resources, this project has contributed to the training of 11 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students, and 1 research assistant professor. Five of the graduate students involved in this four-year project obtained their doctorate, three found employment elsewhere as postdoctoral fellows, one is an assistant professor in an Indian university and one is employed in industry in Florida. The remaining graduate students are continuing with their doctoral research in my lab. I started international collaborations with professors from universities from Germany (Heidelberg University), Japan (Gunma University) and Brazil (University of Santa Maria). These collaborations led to the arrival of three graduate students from those countries that spent two to four-month long research internships in my lab. One of them has already coauthored a publication with members of my group. In terms of dissemination of results, our group published 25 papers in high impact, peer-reviewed journals, and one book chapter; we were also granted an international (PCT) patent on a potential anticancer drug. My students and I presented our results in 8 international, national and regional scientific meetings, and I gave seminars in 22 universities across the U.S., England, Germany, Switzerland, Spain, Japan, and Peru. In 2014, I initiated a æTargeting Excellence: Hispanic Latino Student InitiativeÆ at the University of Louisville. This annual research symposium, held during Hispanic Heritage month, features high-profile Hispanic-American serving as role models for under-represented Hispanic college students.
